title: Follett contract for bookstores (California Community Colleges)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Follett contract for bookstores (California Community Colleges)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting access to records in possession or control of the California Community Colleges for the purposes of inspection and copying pursuant to the California Public Records Act, California Government Code § 7920.000 et seq. (“CPRA”), and Article I, § 3(b) of the California Constitution. The specific records I seek to inspect and copy are listed below. As used herein, “Record” includes “Public Records” and “Writings” as those terms are defined at Government Code § 7920.530 & 7920.545. 

I request copies of 1) any and all contracts or other agreements between Glendale Community College or California Community Colleges and Follett for the campus bookstore at Glendale Community College 2) surveys, feedback or complaints CCC or Glendale Community College has received about the campus bookstore. And 3) revenue, pricing data or other financial information Follett has provided in regards to the GCC store. 

If you contend that any portion of the records requested is exempt from disclosure by express provisions of law, Government Code § 7922.525(b) requires segregation and redaction of that material in order that the remainder of the records may be released. If you contend that any express provision of law exists to exempt from disclosure all or a portion of the records I have requested, Government Code § 7922.535 requires that you notify me of the reasons for the determination not later than 10 days from your receipt of this request. Government Code § 7922.540 requires that any response to this request that includes a determination that the request is denied, in whole or in part, must be in writing and include the name and title of the person(s) responsible for the City’s response.

Government Code § 7922.500 prohibits the use of the 10-day period, or any provisions of the CPRA or any other law, “to delay access for purposes of inspecting public records.”

In responding to this request, please keep in mind that Article 1, § 3(b)(2) of the California Constitution expressly requires you to broadly construe all provisions that further the public’s right of access, and to apply any limitations on access as narrowly as possible.

If I can provide any clarification that will help expedite your attention to my request, please contact me, pursuant to Government Code § 7922.600. I would prefer digital records and ask that you notify me of any duplication costs exceeding $50 before you duplicate the records so that I may decide which records I want copied.

Thank you for your timely attention to this matter. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Molly Peterson on behalf of Adriene Hill

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Follett contract for bookstores (California Community Colleges)
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Peterson:

This email confirms that the Office of General Counsel (OGC) received your request for public records
In accordance with the California Public Records Act (Gov. Code section 6250 et seq.) OGC will determine whether your request seeks disclosable records and send its determination to the email associated with your request within ten (10) days. If your request obligates you to pay a fee for the records, you will receive an invoice and your request will be processed within twenty (20) days after OGC receives payment.
Sincerely,

Public Records Act Unit
Office of General Counsel

Molly Peterson

415.377.1760

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting access to records in possession or control of the California Community Colleges for the purposes of inspection and copying pursuant to the California Public Records Act, California Government Code § 7920.000 et seq. (“CPRA”), and Article I, § 3(b) of the California Constitution. The specific records I seek to inspect and copy are listed below. As used herein, “Record” includes “Public Records” and “Writings” as those terms are defined at Government Code § 7920.530 & 7920.545.

I request copies of 1) any and all contracts or other agreements between Glendale Community College or California Community Colleges and Follett for the campus bookstore at Glendale Community College 2) surveys, feedback or complaints CCC or Glendale Community College has received about the campus bookstore. And 3) revenue, pricing data or other financial information Follett has provided in regards to the GCC store.

If you contend that any portion of the records requested is exempt from disclosure by express provisions of law, Government Code § 7922.525(b) requires segregation and redaction of that material in order that the remainder of the records may be released. If you contend that any express provision of law exists to exempt from disclosure all or a portion of the records I have requested, Government Code § 7922.535 requires that you notify me of the reasons for the determination not later than 10 days from your receipt of this request. Government Code § 7922.540 requires that any response to this request that includes a determination that the request is denied, in whole or in part, must be in writing and include the name and title of the person(s) responsible for the City’s response.

Government Code § 7922.500 prohibits the use of the 10-day period, or any provisions of the CPRA or any other law, “to delay access for purposes of inspecting public records.”

In responding to this request, please keep in mind that Article 1, § 3(b)(2) of the California Constitution expressly requires you to broadly construe all provisions that further the public’s right of access, and to apply any limitations on access as narrowly as possible.

If I can provide any clarification that will help expedite your attention to my request, please contact me, pursuant to Government Code § 7922.600. I would prefer digital records and ask that you notify me of any duplication costs exceeding $50 before you duplicate the records so that I may decide which records I want copied.

Thank you for your timely attention to this matter.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Molly Peterson on behalf of Adriene Hill

title: International Student Optional Practical Training (OPT) Data (2017-2023)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: International Student Optional Practical Training (OPT) Data (2017-2023)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A digital table (.xls, .xlsx, .csv, or similar format) containing information about all F-1 student visa holders who used the Optional Practical Training (OPT) portion of the F-1 visa from 2017-2023, with the following fields of data:
- City of student's address in the U.S.
- State of student's address in the U.S.
- Employer name
- City of employer's address
- State of employer's address
- Student's country of birth
- Student's country of citizenship
- Student's level of education
- Title of first major
- Title of second major
- Degree level (bachelors, masters, doctorate)
- STEM or non-STEM degree
- Name of school
- City of school
- State of school
- City of student's foreign address
- State or province of student's foreign address
- Country of student's foreign address
- Employment start year
- Employment end year
- Actual employment start year
- Actual employment end year

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Steve Tobocman

communications.subject: New Message - 2024-ICFO-36359
communications.communication:
"05/16/2024

Steve Tobocman
MuckRock News, DEPT MR163691
Boston, Massachusetts 02115

RE: ICE FOIA Case Number 2024-ICFO-36359

Dear Requester:

This is the final response to your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) dated 5/15/2024. You are seeking a digital table (.xls, .xlsx, .csv, or similar format) containing information about all F-1 student visa holders who used the Optional Practical Training (OPT) portion of the F-1 visa from 2017-2023.

These documents are on the ICE FOIA Library at https://www.ice.gov/foia/library. Navigate to the Monthly FOIA Releases section and look request ID 2023-ICFO-43657. Due to the large amount of data, each year is broken into multiple spreadsheets (i.e. Part 1, Part 2, etc.).

If you deem this to be an adverse determination, you may exercise your appeal rights. Should you wish to do so, you must send your appeal and a copy of this letter, within 90 days of the date of this letter following the procedures outlined in the DHS FOIA regulations at 6 C.F.R. Part 5 § 5.8. You may submit your appeal electronically at GILDFOIAAppeals@ice.dhs.gov or via regular mail to:

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement
Office of the Principal Legal Advisor
U.S. Department of Homeland Security
500 12th Street, S.W., Mail Stop 5900
Washington, D.C. 20536-5900

Your envelope and letter should be marked “FOIA Appeal.” Copies of the FOIA and DHS regulations are available at www.dhs.gov/foia.

Provisions of FOIA allow DHS to charge for processing fees, up to $25, unless you seek a waiver of fees. In this instance, because the cost is below the $25 minimum, there is no charge.

If you need any further assistance or would like to discuss any aspect of your request, please contact FOIA Public Liaison Daniel Edgington at (866) 633-1182 or 500 12th St. SW Stop 5009 Washington, DC 20536-5009. Additionally, you have a right to right to seek dispute resolution services from the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) which mediates disputes between FOIA requesters and Federal agencies as a non-exclusive alternative to litigation. If you are requesting access to your own records (which is considered a Privacy Act request), you should know that OGIS does not have the authority to handle requests made under the Privacy Act of 1974. You may contact OGIS as follows: Office of Government Information Services, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS, College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, e-mail at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at 202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448.


Sincerely,
ICE FOIA"

title: Thomas Verdillo (1943-2020)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Thomas Verdillo (1943-2020)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records mentioning or concerning Thomas Verdillo, a restaurant owner, and/or the restaurant he owned in Brooklyn, NY named Tommaso. 

Thomas Verdillo is noted as deceased (please see attached news story). Privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7(C) as well as the Privacy Act are therefore diminished. Release of information is in the public interest as Verdillo's restaurant is noted in several books as a meeting place of members of La Cosa Nostra and its Commission, as well as the Westies gang. 

To assist in a records search, the following information is known about Verdillo: 

Full name: Thomas Verdillo   
Year of Birth: 1943
First Five Digits of SSN: 094-32

The following information is furnished regarding the restaurant Tommaso:

DBA: Tommaso
Legal name: Thomas Caterers, Inc.
Premises: 1464 - 1466 86th Street
NY Department of State Company # 283514

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the ELSUR Records System, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies.

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL EMAIL] -  RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1485002-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on “Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request” on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request

If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-0] please enter [1195846-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1195846-1] please enter [1195846-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000
Case Type:
FOIPA
Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)

The FBI’s FOIPA Program is searching the FBI’s indices for potentially responsive documents.

You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Our complex requests are further divided into small (51-250 pages), medium (251-500 pages), large (501-4,999), and extra-large (over 5,000 pages) sub-tracks.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing. Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process.

Currently, simple track cases average approximately 122 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Complex requests in the small processing track are currently averaging 360 days from the date of receipt for processing, those in the medium processing track are currently averaging 1,230 days, those in the large processing track are currently averaging approximately 2,010 days, and those in the extra-large track are averaging 2,370 days.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
200 Constitution Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #FOIL-2022-002-00169
communications.communication:
I am writing to follow up on my FOIA request, which was submitted on 03/09/2022 for communications between the Mayor's Office and the NYPD Homeless Outreach Unit. As of 03/04/2023, I have not received a follow up response or an estimated timeline for when I can expect a response.

I understand that processing FOIA requests can be time-consuming, and I appreciate the work that your agency does to provide transparency and accountability to the public. However, I am eager to obtain this information and would appreciate an update on the status of my request.

Please let me know if there are any further steps I can take or information I can provide to assist in the processing of my request. I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Jordan

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #FOIL-2022-002-00169
communications.communication:
Dear Records Access Officer,

I am writing to appeal the extended response time for my FOIL request FOIL-2022-002-00169. As per the Mayor's Office (OOM) website (https://a860-openrecords.nyc.gov/request/view/FOIL-2022-002-00169), I can expect a response on or about Friday, April 28, 2023.

While I understand that the volume of requests received by the OOM may cause some delays, I believe that this extended response time is not in compliance with the time frame specified by the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL). According to FOIL, agencies are required to respond to requests within five business days, or provide a written acknowledgement of the receipt of the request with an estimated date of response. This response time may only be extended by an additional five business days under certain circumstances.

In addition, I would like to file a complaint with the Open Government Agency regarding this extended response time. I believe that it is unreasonable and does not meet the requirements of FOIL. This extended response time prevents me from obtaining timely access to public records, which is the purpose of FOIL.

Case law has consistently held that an agency's duty to respond to FOIL requests is a clear and non-discretionary obligation. For example, in Matter of Westchester Rockland Newspapers v. Kimball, 50 NY2d 575, 581 (1980), the New York Court of Appeals held that a public agency's failure to comply with the time limits for FOIL responses constituted a denial of access to records. This denial of access can be remedied by mandamus relief through the courts.

I respectfully request that the OOM reconsider this extended response time and provide a response in accordance with FOIL requirements. If there are any specific reasons why this extended response time is necessary, please let me know as soon as possible.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #FOIL-2022-002-00169
communications.communication:
Subject: Urgent Complaint - Repeated and Excessive Delays in Processing FOIA Request - FOIL-2022-002-00169

Dear Sir/Madam,

I am contacting you in a state of growing distress and dissatisfaction concerning the repeated and excessive delays in fulfilling my Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request, numbered FOIL-2022-002-00169.

To provide a brief recap, I initially lodged this request on March 9, 2022, requesting details of all communications between the New York City Police Department and the city in connection to the enforcement or removal of homeless individuals from specified public areas. Despite the provision of FOIL requiring a response within five business days, my request has been continuously extended with the recurring reason of a high volume of requests.

The FOIL request has been extended on the following dates:

November 11, 2022
December 5, 2022
February 2, 2023
March 20, 2023
April 28, 2023
As of today, May 30, 2023, I have been provided a further delayed due date of June 12, 2023. This sustained delay of over a year since the original request is unacceptable and demonstrates a flagrant disregard for the stipulations of FOIL. These continued extensions serve as a barrier to transparency, undermining public trust and preventing an important societal issue from gaining the attention it requires.

Given the clear precedent set in Matter of Westchester Rockland Newspapers v. Kimball, 50 NY2d 575, 581 (1980), an agency's failure to comply with FOIL's response time limits is considered a denial of access to records and can be rectified through mandamus relief via the courts.

This letter serves as an urgent appeal to your office to expedite the release of the requested documents. Moreover, it should be noted that I am seriously contemplating escalating this matter to a higher authority. It is my hope, however, that it does not come to that, and that your office will address this matter swiftly and justly.

I kindly request a definitive date for the fulfillment of my request, considering the substantial delay that has already occurred. Please do not hesitate to contact me if further information is required.

CC: Open Government, New York

Yours Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #FOIL-2022-002-00169

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #FOIL-2022-002-00169
communications.communication:
Mr. Lassiter,



The Committee on Open Government (Committee) is authorized to provide advice and guidance regarding the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL). The Committee cannot compel agencies to act or provide access to records generally because the Committee does possess the requested records. Only the courts, through the filing of an article seventy-eight proceeding in state supreme court, have enforcement authority in this regard.



Please see this advisory opinion<https://docs.dos.ny.gov/coog/ftext/F19355.html>, which explains the structure of FOIL does not allow an agency to repeatedly extend a date certain for a determination. When an agency repeatedly extends a date certain, you may consider your request constructively denied and appeal to the agency on that basis. FOIL provides the agency with ten business days from receipt to determine the appeal. See § 89(4)(a).



Thank you for your inquiry.

Jake Forken
Excelsior Fellow
NYS Committee on Open Government

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #FOIL-2022-002-00169
communications.communication:
Jordan Lassiter

Office of the MayorCity of New YorkCity HallNew York, NY 10007

Subject: Urgent Follow-Up and Intent to Initiate Legal Proceedings – FOIL Request FOIL-2022-002-00169

Dear Records Access Officer,

I am writing to you once again regarding my Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request numbered FOIL-2022-002-00169, originally submitted on March 9, 2022. Despite my repeated appeals and the clear guidance provided by the New York State Committee on Open Government, the response to my request has been subjected to numerous and unjustifiable extensions. As of the latest communication from your office, I am to expect a response by March 19, 2024, marking over two years of delays.

This protracted timeline not only undermines the spirit of transparency and accountability fostered by FOIL but also disregards the statutory requirements set forth by New York State law. The Committee on Open Government has explicitly stated that the structure of FOIL does not permit an agency to indefinitely extend a date certain for determination without constituting a constructive denial of the request.

In light of these circumstances, and following the lack of a satisfactory response to my previous communications and legal notices, I, Jordan Lassiter, hereby inform you of my intent to initiate legal proceedings against the Mayor’s Office for failure to comply with the FOIL. This action is taken in accordance with the advice provided by the Committee on Open Government and supported by established case law, including Matter of Westchester Rockland Newspapers v. Kimball, which recognizes the enforceability of FOIL’s timelines through judicial intervention.

I regret that this matter must escalate to legal proceedings, yet the persistent disregard for my lawful request leaves no alternative. It is my hope that this final notice will prompt your office to reevaluate the handling of FOIL-2022-002-00169 and expedite the release of the requested records without further delay.

Please consider this letter a formal notice of my intent to sue, as required by law. I anticipate taking further legal steps unless a complete response to my request is provided by March 1, 2024.

I look forward to your prompt compliance with this request.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: [Lancaster County, Pennsylvania] Board of Supervisors on "Drag Queen Story Hour"

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: [Lancaster County, Pennsylvania] Board of Supervisors on "Drag Queen Story Hour"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any communications sent to or from any Lancaster County Commissioner (or their aides, secretaries, or assistants) concerning Drag Queen Story Hour, the Lancaster County Library, or the threats of violence over Drag Queen Story Hour.

"Communications" includes, but is not limited to, emails, letters, text messages, social media messages, chats, or other means of one-to-one or one-to-many communication, and any attachments to the communication.

Please also note that this request seeks public records wherever they may be found, including on devices or networks owned or operated by private parties. For example, if an employee uses a personal cell phone or social media account to conduct public business, records created, maintained, or held on the phone or account are public records subject to this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Immediate Disclosure Request Anti-racism training  with Karen Fleshman of Racy Conversations

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Immediate Disclosure Request Anti-racism training  with Karen Fleshman of Racy Conversations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting all information relating to an anti-racism training session that took place the week of April 29, 2024, including the PowerPoint and/or other presentations given by Karen Fleshman and her firm Racy Conversations (http://racyconversations.com/mission-bio).

I am also requesting the contract and terms of Fleshman’s consulting/contracting agreement with SFMTA to include a copy of said contract and all of its terms including financial terms/ payments.

Also please include how Fleshman was chosen to teach this session as well as any other sessions she has taught or will be teaching.

This is a new Immediate Disclosure Requests (SF Admin Code 67.25(a)) directed to your agency and its department head. Your response is required by May 8, 2024. 

Rolling responses are requested (SFAC 67.25(d)) if you are unable to immediately produce records. You must provide exact copies of every responsive record. Do not: print and scan electronic records, provide only the final message in a thread instead of the entire thread, convert native files to PDFs, combine or merge multiple records together, or provide black and white versions of any color record. Provide only copies of records not requiring fees and in-person inspection of all other records (GC 6253).
Your non-exhaustive obligations:
* All withholding of any information must be justified in writing (SFAC 67.27).
* All withholdings by masking or deletion (aka redactions) must be keyed by footnote or other clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld (SFAC 67.26).
* You must respond to emailed requests (SFAC 67.21(b)).
* You must notify us of whether or not responsive records exist and/or were withheld for each request below (Gov Code 6253(c), 6255(b)).
* You must state the name and title of each person responsible for withholding any information (Gov Code 6253(d)).
* Do not impose any end-user restrictions upon me (Santa Clara Co. vs Superior Ct, 170 Cal.App 4th 1301); so if you use a website to publish records, please make them completely public without any login, sign-in, or agreement to any type of terms of use or acceptable use policies.
Your agency must do all of the above things in your response, and you cannot wait until we file complaints.
We have no duty to, and we will not again, remind the City of its obligations. Instead, we will file complaints for each and every Sunshine Ordinance or CPRA violation. We will continue to file complaints until the City’s procedures are modified to fully comply with the Sunshine Ordinance and CPRA, without caveat or exception.

PRESERVE AND DO NOT DESTROY ANY ORIGINALS OF RESPONSIVE RECORDS UNTIL THE FINAL ADJUDICATION OF ANY APPEALS - we will appeal all withholdings or Sunshine violations.

Thank you for your anticipated cooperation in this matter.

NOTE: Please be certain you have properly redacted all of your responses. Once you send them to us, there is no going back. The email address sending this request is a publicly- viewable mailbox. Nothing herein is legal, IT, or professional advice of any kind. The author disclaims all warranties, express or implied, including but not limited to all warranties of merchantability or fitness. In no event shall the author be liable for any special, direct, indirect, consequential, or any other damages whatsoever. The digital signature, if any, in this email is not an indication of a binding agreement or offer; it merely authenticates the sender. Please do not include any confidential information, as I intend that these communications with the City all be disclosable public records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Belle Reve

communications.subject: [External Message Added] City and County of San Francisco public records request #24-2817
communications.communication:
City and County of San Francisco ************************************************************************ A message was sent to you regarding record request #24-2817: The purpose of the immediate disclosure request is to expedite the City’s response to a “simple, routine, or otherwise readily answerable request.” Admin. Code 67.25(a). The Sunshine Ordinance specifies that for more extensive or demanding requests, the maximum deadlines for responding to a request apply. Admin. Code § 67.25(a). Thus, the requester’s designation of a request as an immediate disclosure request does not automatically make it so. Rather, a department may adhere to the time deadlines governing standard requests – an initial 10-day period for response, plus a possible extension of up to 14 additional days – if the extensive or demanding nature of the request would impose an undue burden on the department to respond immediately.  ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City and County of San Francisco.
Technical support: See our help page

communications.communication:
City and County of San Francisco ************************************************************************ A message was sent to you regarding record request #24-2817: I am confirming that we received your Public Records Request today and we assigned it as PRR#24-2817. In your request, you asked for the following:   all information relating to an anti-racism training session that took place the week of April 29, 2024, including the PowerPoint and/or other presentations given by Karen Fleshman and her firm Racy Conversations (http://racyconversations.com/mission-bio). I am also requesting the contract and terms of Fleshman’s consulting/contracting agreement with SFMTA to include a copy of said contract and all of its terms including financial terms/ payments. Also please include how Fleshman was chosen to teach this session as well as any other sessions she has taught or will be teaching.   If I misunderstood your request, please let me know immediately.   Our department will identify and compile the requested information. The Sunshine Ordinance requires departments to respond as soon as possible or within ten calendar days from receipt of any records requests. Therefore, I will contact you as soon as the responsive documents are ready and will do so on or before May 20, 2024, as permitted by San Francisco Administrative Code § 67.21(b) and California Government Code § 6253(c). Sincerely, Caroline Celaya Manager, Public Records Requests  San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency 1 South Van Ness Avenue, 7th floor San Francisco, CA 94103 ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at City and County of San Francisco.
Technical support: See our help page

  *  the date you made your original request for information; and a copy of your original request for information, or if you are unable to provide a copy, a description of your original request for information. You may also submit written comments stating why you think the information should be released to you, but you are not required to do so. Send your appeal by mail to the attorney general at: Open Records Division P.O. Box 12548 Austin, Texas 78711-2548 Within forty-five business days after receiving all of the above-listed items necessary to file your appeal, the attorney general will issue a written ruling on the matter.  You will receive a copy of this ruling in the mail.

title: Call for Service’ log,  Daily Dispatch Log, Police Blotter or 911 Call Log. 12.30.2018 (South Sound 911)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Call for Service’ log,  Daily Dispatch Log, Police Blotter or 911 Call Log. 12.30.2018 (South Sound 911)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting Call for Service’ log, known also as the Daily Dispatch Log, Police Blotter or 911 Call Log specifically for the date of 12/30/2018.  I'm seeking  Calls for Service, the respective incident numbers, time of incident, location of incident and type of incident on 12/30/18 only, between the hours of midnight and noon.

It is my understanding, pursuant to a U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit decision, U.S. v. Garcia, No. 92-30384 (1993), that dispatch logs are public records, therefore disclosable.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Candice Ahlstrand

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: Call for Service’ log,  Daily Dispatch Log, Police Blotter or 911 Call Log. 12.30.2018 (South Sound 911)
communications.communication:
Ms. Ahlstrand,

Your request has been forwarded to South Sound 911’s public records officer.

Your message was originally blocked by the agency’s spam filter. In future, to avoid any delays in the processing of your request, please submit public records requests online at http://www.southsound911.org/157/Public-Records-Requests.

If you do not already have an account, you will need to create one to submit your request using the Records Portal. Using the online portal ensures that the records specialist has all of the information needed to process your request. It also offers the convenience of receiving records electronically.
If you would instead prefer to mail future public records requests, please send them to South Sound 911, ATTN: Records Custodian, 955 Tacoma Ave. S., Suite 202; Tacoma, WA 98402.
Regards,
South Sound 911

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #W173590-050619
communications.communication:
Hello,

I received the attached letter from you on 10/9/23. Since the request you are referring to, W173590 has been deleted due to retention (2 years), we no longer have that request in your system. I recreated the request for you on 10/9/23 under the new reference number of W392541. The below was emailed to you on 10/9/23.


View Message

Subject: South Sound 911 Records Request :: W392541-100923
Body:
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

10/09/2023

Candice Ahlstrand

Agency or Business: Lucy Parsons Labs


RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of 10/9/2023, Reference # W392541-100923

Dear Candice,

South Sound 911 received a public records request from you on 10/9/2023.

Your request details as follows:

Type of Record(s) Requested: CAD Log
Type of Incident: Other/Unknown
Municipality:
Case/Incident#
Incident Details: I am requesting call for service log, known also as the Daily Dispatch log, Police Blotter or 911 Call log specifically for the date of 12/30/2018. I'm seeking Calls for Service, the respective incident numbers, time of incident, location of incident and type of incident on 12/30/18 only, between the hours of midnight and noon.

South Sound 911 has reviewed its files and has located responsive records to your request. We have made every attempt to weed out duplicates or blank pages; however, sometimes these issues do occur.

Please log in to the Records Center here<https://public-southsound911.mycusthelp.com/WEBAPP/_rs/Login.aspx> to retrieve the appropriate response.

Sincerely,

Disclosure Unit
South Sound 911



Below are directions on how to log into the portal and view your completed request that was closed out and finished on 10/9/23. South Sound 911 considers this request closed. The PRA’s one year statue of limitations to seek judicial review has started to run because the agency does not intend to further address the request and the requestor may ask follow-up questions within 10 days.

You can log into our portal to review your request by using the link below.

https://southsound911.org/public-records-requests/

Then selecting the, “Public Records Portal” button.

[cid:image002.jpg@01DAA6B8.DE279420]
Then select the, “View My Requests” button.

[cid:image003.jpg@01DAA6B8.DE279420]

You will then input your email address and password.

You will be able to view or download the CAD logs requests. Please let me know if you have problems logging into portal. I would be happy to assist you.
Best wishes,

Tina Klein
Records Manager – Information Services
(253) 287-4701
[Description: Description: SS911-Logo_SIGNATURE]

title: Gainesville Police Department Request

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Gainesville Police Department Request
communications.communication:
To Whom it may concern,
Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:
Any and all records from the past year regarding your nuisance property ordinance that will be referred to as ordinance in this request but could be known (but not limited to) as Nuisances, Public Nuisance Abatement as described in Chapter 16, Article V of the city code.
Please provide any and all written records (including but not limited to hard-copy documents, memos, emails, word processor documents, PDF documents, PowerPoint files, images files, video files etc.) regarding the Ordinance including but not limited to:
• police calls, reports, citations, or arrests, collected by the municipality police department for the purpose of enforcing the ordinance
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request.
Sincerely,
Jenny Wadhwa

communications.subject: Public Record Request- Nuisance Property Ordinance Reports
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon Jenny Wadhwa,

This email confirms receipt of your public record requests for reports pertaining to Nuisance Property Ordinance for the Gainesville Police Department.  In your request, you mentioned receiving police calls, reports, citations, etc.  Our agency does not handle police calls.  You will need to contact the Alachua County Combined Communication Center.  They can be reached at  audioproduction@alachuasheriff.org<mailto:audioproduction@alachuasheriff.org> or (352) 264-6688.

In regards to reports, I provided an excel spreadsheet of the case report numbers and charges.  Please be advised, there are over 300 arrest report numbers that are on this list.  It will take many hours to review and redact the arrest reports and incident reports.  We will need a deposit before we can begin the work.  Please advise if you are still interested in this request.
Thanks,


Veronica L. Rochelle
Police Records Shift Supervisor
Gainesville Police Department
(352) 393-7562

communications.subject: RE: Public Record Request- Nuisance Property Ordinance Reports
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon,

It has been a month and I have not received a response.  This request will be cancelled.  If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me.
Thanks,


Veronica L. Rochelle
Police Records Shift Supervisor
Gainesville Police Department
(352) 393-7562

title: FEMA buyouts

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FEMA buyouts
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Access to and copies of electronic database tables containing the data in the possession and/or control of FEMA in association with property acquisitions under the Hazard Mitigation Grant program or similar program(s). The tables should include these fields, and any other data fields present in the dataset: the address of the properties acquired, the sellers' names, the amount paid for the property and the GIS coordinates of the properties. I am requesting data covering all activity of the program since its inception. 

I would also like any documentation or meta-data associated with any and all data tables related to the dataset named above. This documentation would include but not be limited to any coding manuals, record layouts, relational models and data dictionaries, including all references to any fields withheld by FEMA in response to this request.

I request that you release these data to me in a standard, machine-readable electronic format such as Excel, Access, ASCII, CSV, etc. 

In the event that any of the records are exempt from disclosure, I ask that you segregate those portions that are not exempt from disclosure and release them to me.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Scott Dance

communications.subject: 2022-FEFO-00052FEMA FOIA 2022-FEFO-00052 Acknowledgement
communications.communication: October 22, 2021  SENT VIA E-MAIL TO: 119825-38295155@requests.muckrock.com Re: FOIA Request Number 2022-FEFO-00052 Acknowledgment Dear Scott Dance: This email acknowledges receipt of your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), dated October 20, 2021 and received in this office on October 20, 2021 .  You are seeking The following:-electronic database tables containing the data in the possession and/or control of FEMA in association with property acquisitions under the Hazard Mitigation Grant program or similar program(s). The tables should include these fields, and any other data fields present in the dataset: the address of the properties acquired, the sellers' names, the amount paid for the property and the GIS coordinates of the properties.-any documentation or meta-data associated with any and all data tables related to the dataset named above. This documentation would include but not be limited to any coding manuals, record layouts, relational models and data dictionaries, including all references to any fields withheld by FEMA in response to this request. Your request has been assigned the following tracking number 2022-FEFO-00052 . Due to current working conditions in response to the COVID -19 outbreak, please expect a delay in our response.  Please be assured that we continue our commitment to provide timely FOIA responses and are processing your FOIA request as soon as possible. If you have any questions or would like to discuss thismatter, please contact me the assigned FOIA specialist directly at, juan.vegasandoval@fema.dhs.gov . If you require additional support,you may also contact FEMA’s Public Liaison atFEMA-FOIA@fema.dhs.gov.  If you need to contact FEMA’s FOIA PublicLiaison, then please reference the FOIA request number and addressyour email to “Attn: FEMA’s Public Liaison” and summarize your concerns.  We may contact you again  about more information about your FOIA request. You have been placed in the fee requester category “Commercial Use” requester, pursuant to the DHS FOIA Regulations, 6 CFR §5.11. Provisions of the FOIA allow us to recover part of the cost of complying with your request.  We shall charge you for records in accordance with the DHS FOIA regulations as they apply to commercial requesters for the information .  We will construe the submission of your request as an agreement to pay up to $25.00.  This office will contact you before accruing any further fees. that is not considered yourPrivacy Act information . As a commercial requester of this type of informationyou may be charged 10 cents per page for duplication, and for search and review time at the per quarter-hour rate ($4.00 for clerical personnel, $7.00 for professional personnel, $10.25 for managerial personnel) of the searcher and reviewer Accordingly, the FOIA provides that you may be charged certain fees for the processing of your FOIA request. We will query theappropriate offices within FEMA who may have the records you are seeking todetermine if fees will apply. Then we will contact you again once ourcalculations are completed and notify you before proceeding further with theprocessing of your FOIA request. In the event that you are charged fees, we invite you to reach out to our Office to discuss how to narrow your request and reduce the fees assessed. We appreciate your patience . If you have any questions or would like to discuss this matter, pleasecontact the assigned FOIA specialist directly at, juan.vegasandoval@fema.dhs.gov andreference the request number 2022-FEFO-00052 . Again, ifyou require additional support, you may also contact FEMA’s PublicLiaison at FEMA-FOIA@fema.dhs.gov.  If you need to contact FEMA’s FOIAPublic Liaison, then please reference the FOIA request number andaddress your email to “Attn: FEMA’s Public Liaison” and summarize yourconcerns. You may also contact FEMAat (202) 646-3323, or you may contact FEMA’s Public Liaison in the samemanner.  Please reference FOIA request number 2022-FEFO-00052. For a faster responseplease communicate by email. Thank you for your interest in FEMA. Sincerely, Disclosure Branch Information Management Division Office of the Chief Administrative Officer Federal Emergency Management Agency U.S. Department of Homeland Security

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2022-FEFO-00052
communications.communication:
Hello,

I am writing to justify a fee waiver request for 2022-FEFO-00052.

I am not a commercial requester -- I am a member of the media. I am a reporter at The Baltimore Sun and I intend to use the documents I am requesting in an article or series of articles. I am employing the services of Muck Rock to handle this FOIA request, but it should have been more clear that I am requesting these documents as an employee of The Baltimore Sun. I have no commercial interest in the disclosure of these records.

Fees should be waived for this request because the data I am requesting concerns government operations -- specifically, the use of government funds to buy properties in areas vulnerable to flooding and other climate change related threats. The disclosure of this information, through my reporting for The Baltimore Sun, would serve to help the public better understand what the government is doing and how taxpayer money is being spent to help property owners deal with climate threats, to protect lives and property from damage, and generally prepare for extreme weather coming as a result of climate change. The public understanding to be gained from this disclosure is significant because there has been little reporting around these buyout efforts, and yet they are expected to grow in scale through expanded investment by the federal government in the coming years and decades. Most people are not aware of this buyout activity at all, or if they are little is understood about where it is happening and how often these buyouts are occurring.

I appreciate the consideration of my fee waiver request.

Sincerely, 
Scott Dance

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2022-FEFO-00052
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

After further discussion with the appropriate program office, is it possible to further narrow your FOIA request?

The current scope will take a an extensive amount of time to produce and we want to see how you to provide you with the records you needs in a timely manner. Would you be willing to limit the scope of your FOIA request? Specifically part 2 of your FOIA request that is seeking for documentation. The data pull may be more feasible than the documentation records.

If you can please provide a response by January 17, 2022, that would be great.

We look forward to your response and thank you for your cooperation.

Sincerely,


Juan Vega
Government Information Specialist | Information Management Division | Office of the Chief Administrative Officer
Office: (202) 646-3323 | Work Mobile: (202) 674-2989

Just the data pull would be great. Thank you.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2022-FEFO-00052
communications.communication:
Thank you for your quick response.

Once you confirm the following, we will make sure to continue processing your FOIA request:


  *   You are seeking an electronic database tables in the possession and/or control of FEMA in association with property acquisitions under the Hazard Mitigation Grant program or similar program(s). The tables should include these fields, and any other data fields present in the dataset:

     *   the address of the properties acquired,
     *   the sellers' names,
     *   the amount paid for the property
     *   the GIS coordinates of the properties.

Please let me know if there is any additional data fields that you are seeking that are not listed above. Please note that address, GIS coordinates and seller information may be withheld under exemption 6 of the FOIA due to Personally Identifiable Information (PII).

If you can please provide a response by January 25, 2022, that would be great.

If no response is provided then we will assume you agree with the adjustments to your FOIA request listed above.

We look forward to your response and thank you for your cooperation with us.

Sincerely,


Juan Vega
Government Information Specialist | Information Management Division | Office of the Chief Administrative Officer
Office: (202) 646-3323 | Work Mobile: (202) 674-2989
juan.vegasandoval@fema.dhs.gov<mailto:juan.vegasandoval@fema.dhs.gov>

Federal Emergency Management Agency

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2022-FEFO-00052
communications.communication:
Hi Juan,

I understand that sellers' names is considered personally identifiable information and may be withheld. But there is precedent for FEMA to release addresses of properties purchased in buyouts. This data was released to NPR in 2019: https://www.npr.org/2019/03/05/696995788/search-the-thousands-of-disaster-buyouts-fema-didnt-want-you-to-see

I am simply asking for the same data that was already provided for NPR, but including more recent buyouts as well. Therefore, address information should not be redacted from any data you provide.

Scott

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #2022-FEFO-00052
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

This email is regarding your FOIA request 2022-FEFO-00052.

After further discussion with the program office, can you please specify the additional data fields other than those 3 previously listed?

I was able to open the NPR link you previously provided (Whiter Communities Received More Federal Buyouts After Disasters : NPR<https://www.npr.org/2019/03/05/696995788/search-the-thousands-of-disaster-buyouts-fema-didnt-want-you-to-see>) and was able to download the CSV file from that link. NPR includes the following data fields they received:

  *   Fiscal Year
  *   Disaster Description
  *   Residence
  *   Owner
  *   Structure
  *   Address City
  *   State
  *   Zip
  *   Price Paid
  *   Status

Can you please confirm that you are seeking these same data fields along with the "GIS Coordinates of the properties" but updated as of October, 2021?

If you can please provide a response by February 24, 2022, that would be great. We want to make sure we provide you with the data you are specifically seeking.

We look forward to your response and thank you for your cooperation.

Sincerely.



Juan Vega
Government Information Specialist | Information Management Division | Office of the Chief Administrative Officer
Office: (202) 646-3323 | Work Mobile: (202) 674-2989

title: FOIA Request for Alvin Community College

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: FOIA Request for Alvin Community College
communications.communication:
To Whom it May Concern: 

I am writing to request access to and copies of records under the Texas Public Information Act. 

In particular, we are submitting a commercial FOIA request to Alvin Community College for an existing, already maintained electronic record (without copying, scanning, or printing) of purchase orders dated 2015-06-15 onward. The information requested is: 

1. Purchase order number or equivalent
2. Purchase date
3. Line item details
4. Line item quantity
5. Line item price
6. Vendor ID number, name, address, contact person, and email address.

Importantly, a similar request was recently made by SmartProcure and you might already have files referencing this information. If it's easier, please feel free to share the same information with us that you did with them. Please email the information to justin@starbridge.ai. If this request is misrouted, please forward to the correct contact person and reply to this communication with the name and information of the recipient.

Sincerely,
Justin Wenig

communications.subject: RE: Texas Public Information Act Request: FOIA Request for Alvin Community College

I wanted to follow up on the following Texas Public Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on April 26, 2024. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: : Texas Public Information Act Request: FOIA Request for Alvin Community College

Good afternoon,

The college is collecting records responsive to your request, and we should have responsive documents to you in the next two days.

Thank you,

----

Sincerely,

The Riford Family

title: Ralph Bunche

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Ralph Bunche
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of inquiry or investigation of Ralph Johnson Bunche (August 7, 1904 - December 9, 1971). Proof of death is not required as his date of birth was over 100 years ago.

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies at FBI Headquarters. Please also conduct a search for records at the Alexandria Records Center. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

title: Soviet Possession of FBI Communications

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Soviet Possession of FBI Communications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of file 65-HQ-67348, titled "Soviet Possession of FBI Communications". 

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records (including sub files) and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Paul Galante

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Soviet Possession of FBI Communications
communications.communication:
Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 134 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 523 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,335 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,875 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS) FBI-Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive, Winchester, VA 22602-4843
Direct: (540) 868-4593
Fax: (540) 868-4391
Questions E-mail: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1409894-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 138 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 571 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,289 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,649 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS) FBI-Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive, Winchester, VA 22602-4843
Direct: (540) 868-4593
Fax: (540) 868-4391
Questions E-mail: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

the "Renew" button in the file list.

title: Unidentified Deceased Persons Information - Tuolumne County

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Unidentified Deceased Persons Information - Tuolumne County
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any information regarding the total number of active unidentified deceased persons cases ("John Doe" or "Jane Doe" cases) that the Tuolumne County Coroner's Office (https://www.tuolumnecounty.ca.gov/344/CivilCoronerRecords-Section) is currently responsible for, dating from the earliest possible case on record, to the active case opened the closest of the date that this request is received.

Please conduct the broadest possible search for any information (excel files, PowerPoint Presentations, Word documents, PDFs, email correspondence with the DOJ's NamUs program, CJIS correspondence, NCIC correspondence, etc.) that would help to definitively state the total number of unidentified deceased persons that the Tuolumne County Coroner's Office is responsible for.

I research missing and unidentified person cases as a hobby, and I am curious as to why Merced, Fresno, Mariposa, Stanislaus, and other California counties report unidentified person cases yet Tuolumne does not. I am curious to know how many (total number) and the circumstances of any cases in Tuolumne County - if they exist.

Thank you for the Tuolumne County Sheriff's Office for their commitment to transparency.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Unidentified Deceased Persons Information - Tuolumne County
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following California Public Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on April 30, 2024. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Jane Jon Doe request
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon,
This email responds to your request for public records (below)  dated 04/30/2024.  After review of our records Tuolumne County Sheriff - Coroners Office has 1 Jon/Jane Doe case.
Thank you for your patience to our response.

To Whom It May Concern:
Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:Any information regarding the total number of active unidentified deceased persons cases ("John Doe" or "Jane Doe" cases) that the Tuolumne County Coroner's Office (https://www.tuolumnecounty.ca.gov/344/CivilCoronerRecords-Section) is currently responsible for, dating from the earliest possible case on record, to the active case opened the closest of the date that this request is received.Please conduct the broadest possible search for any information (excel files, PowerPoint Presentations, Word documents, PDFs, email correspondence with the DOJ's NamUs program, CJIS correspondence, NCIC correspondence, etc.) that would help to definitively state the total number of unidentified deceased persons that the Tuolumne County Coroner's Office is responsible for.I research missing and unidentified person cases as a hobby, and I am curious as to why Merced, Fresno, Mariposa, Stanislaus, and other California counties report unidentified person cases yet Tuolumne does not. I am curious to know how many (total number) and the circumstances of any cases in Tuolumne County - if they exist.Thank you for the Tuolumne County Sheriff's Office for their commitment to transparency.The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.


Kind Regards,

Deni Avery -Records Supervisor
Criminal-Civil-CCW Divisions
209-533-5836

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Rose Terse 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fking-county-sheriffs-office-2399%252Fiapro-internal-investigations-161731%252F%253Femail%253Dkcso%252540mycusthelp.net&url_auth_token=AAATlkMFitx2rEEBFUawwtUL2VE%3A1rtdX3%3A3gmRVjbfsb7KX1a_hb0QXSmxIuxy02LrYORAnBtYuX0” The KCSO Public Disclosure Unit is experiencing a high volume of open requests, nearly 1,500 of which came in prior to your request. The information requested is not a report maintained by the KCSO, therefore, we will perform a custom search and extraction of data available to us. We have interpreted your request for "internal investigations" as IIU events and UOF-Use of Force - and not administrative events (i.e. SAL-supervisor action log, NIM-non-investigative matter, P-pursuit, DRB-driving review board, FD-Firearm Discharge, COM-Commendation, etc.) unless clarification is provided. Also, please provide a date range for our search. If we don't hear from you by , we will proceed with searching for only IIU and UOF for a date range of 5-years. As such, you can expect a response by April 23, 2024 July 12, 2024. If we are unable to meet this self-imposed disclosure date, we will let you know. If we are able to provide an update sooner, we will certainly do so. Your request is subject to fees as allowed under King County Ordinance 18949 and the Public Records Act, RCW 42.56.120. Please visit our and select "What is the cost to obtain records" for more information. Once we have determined the scope of your request and responsive records, we may provide an estimate for fees requiring 10% down prior to processing your request. website  PLEASE NOTE: Per RCW 42.56.120(4), the KCSO reserves the right to close a records request after 30 days if a requester does not inspect, view, download, and/or pick up the records we provide. There is no obligation for us to continue producing records that are not being collected by a requester. RCW 42.56.120(4) states that if an installment of a records request is not claimed or reviewed, the agency is not obligated to fulfill the balance of the request. WAC 44-14-04006(1) states that a records request has been fulfilled and can be closed if an entirely unclear request has not been clarified,a request or installment has not been claimed or reviewed, or the requester cancels the request. 
Please reply directly to this message or log in to the Online Request System if you have any questions or would like to clarify or cancel this request. Sincerely, Kimberly Petty | Legal & Public Disclosure Program Manager Public Disclosure Unit | Support Services King County Sheriff's Office www.kingcounty.gov/sheriff
